posts.cooked: Hi, We are trying to use a andymark linear actuator for our robot, and we were wondering how do you program it? We plugged it into the roborio pwm ports and we programmed it as a servo but it doesnt work. How do you do it?

posts.name: Peyton Yeung
posts.cooked: Be sure to verify the servo is plugged in with the correct orientation (white wire toward the center of the rio). Do note that the rio seems to output .6-2.4 ms for PWM signals and the linear servos accept 1-2ms signals.
We made sure it is plugged in correctly, could you explain a little bit more what you are talking about with the timings?

posts.name: Peyton Yeung
posts.cooked:
From the WPILib doc, the Rio outputs a pulse range of 0.6 ms - 2.4 ms pulse width for PWM devices. The data sheet for the linear servo lists that the servo accepts PWM signals from 1-2 ms in pulse width. If you are using the Scaled Value *method and commanding the servo to move for example

exampleServo.set(0.0); that is outsider the range the servo will accept and it likely will not move. Same for exampleServo.set(1.0);

You need to be sending a value of ~0.22 to ~0.78.

*Scaled Value - Sets the servo position using a scaled 0 to 1.0 value. 0 corresponds to one extreme of the servo and 1.0 corresponds to the other

link_counts.title: Repeatable Low Power Movement - Controlling Servos with WPILib — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
Make sure the actuator is plugged into the PWM slot specified in your program.

You can use setBoundsMicroseconds to modify the range of PWM pulse width so you can use 0.0 and 1.0 as bounds with set .

myServo.setBoundsMicroseconds(2000, 1500, 1500, 1500, 1000);

It’s nice to have a servo tester around to make sure that the actuator is in good working order.

link_counts.title: Amazon.com: DIYmall HJ Digital RC Servo Tester ESC Consistency Tester Speed Controller for RC Helicopter Airplane Car Motor Throttle Display : Toys & Games

posts.cooked: Thank you for the help! That worked for us
